Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Ecosystem processes in regenerating tropical dry forests: linking plant functional traits, stands, and landscapes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical dry forests have unique biodiversity and high potential for carbon sequestration, but they have been greatly reduced in area by deforestation. In countries such as Costa Rica, dry forests are now regenerating following centuries of grazing. The goal of this project is to determine how tropical dry forest carbon dynamics (i.e. processes like photosynthesis that add carbon to the ecosystem or decomposition that remove it) depend upon plant characteristics, disturbance history, and environmental factors. The methods include experimental studies of seedling growth and traits, observations of forest-level carbon dynamics in plots that vary in soils and forest age, and computer modeling of carbon dynamics.

Results of these studies will: 1) provide benchmark, long-term datasets of carbon dynamics in dry forests, and 2) by extrapolating to coarser spatial and temporal scales, forecast how tropical dry forests worldwide may respond to changes in climate and land use. Educational activities include training advanced undergraduate students in tropical ecology through a field course, increasing ecological literacy by development of active learning materials for undergraduate non-majors courses, and developing materials on tropical dry forest ecology that will be distributed to thousands of Costa Rican school children.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical forests are important globally because they capture and store vast amounts of carbon and they house over 50% of the planet’s terrestrial biodiversity.  There is large variation in climate and soils among tropical forests, and not all tropical forests function in the same way.  For example, seasonally dry tropical forests experience lower levels of rainfall compared to tropical rainforests, and the rain that does fall is typically concentrated during the wet season, which alternates with a long dry season (Figure 1 a and b).  Despite the large amount of area accounted for by seasonally dry tropical  forests (SDTF)—some people estimate that up to 40% of all tropical forests should be classified as SDTF—these forests have not received as much scientific study as tropical rainforests.  There are many gaps in our understanding of the structure and function of SDTF that hinder our ability to predict how these unique and important forests will respond to changes in climate and land use.  Therefore, the overall goals of this project were to: 1) characterize differences in important functional characteristics among tree species that determine how these species respond to variation in environmental conditions such as light and soil water and nutrients, 2) understand ecosystem processes in SDTF such as forest growth, and how this varies at the regional scale in response to variation among years in annual rainfall and different soil conditions, and 3) incorporate this new knowledge into a simulation model of SDTF dynamics, to enable us to predict changes in the structure and functioning of these ecosystems as the climate changes.  A fourth and equally important goal of the project was to increase awareness of SDTF to a range of stakeholder groups including undergraduates at the University of Minnesota, elementary school children in northwest Costa Rica, and staff of the Guanacaste Conservation Area in Costa Rica, where the research was conducted.

     To accomplish these goals, we conducted a number of field experiments and observations, which resulted in over 30 publications in the scientific literature.  For example, in several of these experiments we grew large numbers of tree species under different environmental conditions in a shadehouse (Figure 1 c), and measured responses such as growth, nitrogen accumulation in plant tissue, and physiological variables such as photosynthetic rates.  Several themes emerged from these studies.  First, while there is large variation in how species respond to environmental conditions and resources, species from the legume family (Fabaceae) consistently grow faster than other species and seem to have efficient ways to conserve water in these dry forests.  These traits may explain why legumes trees are particularly abundant in SDTF.  Second, soil nutrients and water constrain seedling growth and physiology as much as light, which contrasts with tropical rainforests that are strongly light limited.  We also discovered that forest growth and soil nutrient dynamics vary predictably over gradients of forest age and in response to rainfall.  These results helped us develop a new version of the simulation model Ecosystem Demography 2 (ED2), with four plant types that represent the diversity of trees in SDTF. 

     Collectively, this research has greatly advanced our understanding of SDTF and their potential responses to changing climate and land use.  In addition, this project resulted in the training of 15 undergraduates from the United States, the training of two graduate students and one postdoctoral research fellow (now an assistant professor at Utah State University of Minnesota), a coloring book for local Costa Rican school children (Figure 1 d), and two Research Open House events hosted at the Guanacaste Conservation Area to build linkages between researchers and managers of the Conservation Area.
